meta.article_title: July 22, 2024 - Eleven Points on Match Etiquette

eleven_points_on_match_etiquette.probleme: Players are unsure of proper match etiquette and small procedural rules.

debutant: Know key rules and procedures, including coin flip/ball hide to choose serve/receive/side and two-minute warmup norms.
Examine opponent’s racket at the start without rubbing the playing surface; if testing, touch along the edge only.
Use the one-minute break between games or a single timeout for focus, tactics with coach, or rest; towel every six points.
Understand coaching limits: one coach (except team events), coaching only between points; do not leave play to consult except between games or timeout.
Return stray balls properly: float them back with backspin to the opponent’s hands if distant.
Limit conversation to match business; avoid engaging with psychological ploys.
In team events, anyone from the bench may coach; otherwise only one coach.
If there’s a dispute, call an umpire; referees rule on rules but usually don’t umpire.
After the match, exchange hand/fist/racket bumps, record scores (usually by winner), and return the slip.
intermediaire: Warm up about one minute FH-to-FH and one minute BH-to-BH; combination-racket users may choose which side to show.
Use discreet signals or a language the opponent doesn’t understand for brief between-point coaching, where permitted.

erreurs_a_eviter: Rubbing fingers on an opponent’s rubber surface.
Ignoring time limits for warmup, timeouts, and toweling.
Talking beyond match business once play has started.
Smacking stray balls back without control.

meta.article_title: July 15, 2024 - The Power of a Stare

the_power_of_a_stare.probleme: Difficulty controlling nerves and maintaining focus amid distractions.
the_power_of_a_stare.diagnostic: External distractions (spectators, lights, umpire, background) and internal distractions (emotions, nervousness, wandering thoughts) disrupt concentration.

debutant: Use a 5–10 second deliberate stare at an object (nearby or distant) during the match while clearing your mind and breathing deeply; then refocus on play.
intermediaire: Apply the same 5–10 second reset before serving or receiving when nerves spike.
avance: Some players combine the focus reset with staring at the opponent before serving, which may also unsettle them.

erreurs_a_eviter: Letting internal or external distractions accumulate without a reset routine.

meta.article_title: July 8, 2024 - Stop Trying to Fix a Stroke While Hitting a Ball

stop_trying_to_fix_a_stroke_while_hittin.probleme: Players attempt to change technique while simultaneously timing incoming balls.
stop_trying_to_fix_a_stroke_while_hittin.diagnostic: Doing both at once leads to subconscious compensations that corrupt the new technique.

debutant: Shadow-practice the corrected stroke repeatedly until the motion is mostly ingrained.
intermediaire: Only after the shadowed motion is stable, move to the table and adjust timing to the ball while preserving the new mechanics.
avance: Separate skill components during learning (e.g., mechanics first, then integrate with ball timing), similar to mastering sub-skills before combining them.

erreurs_a_eviter: Jumping straight to ball drills when changing stroke mechanics.
Letting timing demands reshape the intended technique.

meta.article_title: July 1, 2024 - Should You Guard Against the Long or Short Serve?

should_you_guard_against_the_long_or_sho.probleme: Uncertainty about whether to position for long or short serves.
should_you_guard_against_the_long_or_sho.diagnostic: Different players and situations call for different default guards.

debutant: Recognize there is no universal rule; it depends on your receiving strengths and the opponent’s serve quality.
intermediaire: If struggling to move in on short serves, stand closer and rely on reflexes against long ones.
If the opponent’s deep breaking serve is the main threat, assume it is coming and guard for it each point.
avance: Prepare for all serves but bias your stance toward the serve type that most threatens you or best suits your style; adjust during the match.

erreurs_a_eviter: Rigidly guarding the same way regardless of opponent or your own tendencies.

meta.article_title: June 24, 2024 - Leave Your Comfort Zone to Develop Strategically

leave_your_comfort_zone_to_develop_strat.probleme: Stagnation from staying within comfort-zone techniques.
leave_your_comfort_zone_to_develop_strat.diagnostic: Avoiding new techniques prevents reaching full potential; example given of lacking a backhand attack leading to predictable counters.

debutant: Identify new techniques to add (strategic thinking with coach or peers).
intermediaire: Practice new techniques extensively; expect temporary losses while integrating them in matches.
Introduce them first versus weaker players, then peers, ideally in practice matches or lower-stakes events.
avance: Aim to welcome the new technique into your comfort zone so opponents cannot key on old patterns.

erreurs_a_eviter: Relying solely on existing strengths and never deploying new skills in live play.

the_surprise_test.probleme: Negative reactions to misses and lack of confident execution.
the_surprise_test.diagnostic: Players react with anger or disgust rather than surprise, indicating they do not expect to make their shots.

debutant: Adopt the mindset that you expect to make every shot; let training (subconscious) execute.
intermediaire: Remove pressure by not fixating on winning each point; this enables the expectation to take root.
avance: Practice until the expectation aligns with reality so misses become surprising exceptions unless the opponent forces errors.

erreurs_a_eviter: Letting anger/disgust be the first reaction to errors.
Believing you must already be elite before expecting makes.

meta.article_title: June 10, 2024 - Hitting to the Same Spot Twice

hitting_to_the_same_spot_twice.probleme: Predictable placement that alternates spots and lets opponents recover.
hitting_to_the_same_spot_twice.diagnostic: Players often only use two of the three key locations (wide FH, wide BH, middle) and automatically change spots after pulling an opponent out of position.

debutant: Be aware of all three placement spots: wide forehand, wide backhand, and middle.
intermediaire: After drawing the opponent out of position, sometimes play to the same spot twice to exploit recovery movements.
Apply the same logic to the middle: attack middle twice as opponent vacates it.
avance: Use consecutive same-spot attacks to force opposite recovery moves and simplify your own shot selection.

erreurs_a_eviter: Automatically switching to a different spot after the first placement.
Ignoring the middle as a target.

down_the_line_training.probleme: Insufficient ability and confidence to attack down the line.
down_the_line_training.diagnostic: Players underuse the whole table; down-the-line has a shorter target (9 ft vs. ~10 ft 3.5 in crosscourt) but builds accuracy for both directions.

debutant: Practice attacking down the line (FH or BH) while a partner blocks; focus on consistency and placement.
intermediaire: For FH, adjust stance (right foot more back for right-handers), turn shoulders, and contact a bit later relative to the body.
Let the ball come out more or step in with body rotation to hit at normal timing while contacting later relative to your body.
avance: Advanced variation: counterloop down the line.
Constraint drill: block off the inner half of each court half with towels to force balls within ~15 inches of the sideline; prefer misses wide rather than toward the middle.
Optional finisher: after five or more strong down-the-line shots, end with a crosscourt winner at a target.

exercices_complementaires.description: Place towels to block inner halves; attacker plays down the line within ~15 inches of sideline while partner blocks; emphasizes wide placement.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: towels or long object as lane markers, table tennis table, partner

exercices_complementaires.description: Make five or more strong down-the-line attacks, then attempt a crosscourt winner aimed at a placed target.
exercices_complementaires.materiel: small target object, table tennis table, partner

erreurs_a_eviter: Training only crosscourt and neglecting down-the-line accuracy.
